channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Gao Yubao on Documenting Unit 731’s Brutal Human Experiments
item.description: Gao Yubao, head of research at the Museum of War Crime Evidence by Japanese Army Unit 731, describes the goal of the institution and the architecture behind it.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors to the Museum of War Crime Evidence by Japanese Army Unit 731 examining medical instruments used in experiments on prisoners.

item.title: World Briefing: Spanish Police Arrest Treasurer of Catalan Governing Party
item.description: The Spanish police raided the headquarters of the Convergence party and arrested a dozen people in an investigation into whether companies paid bribes for public works contracts.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Quantum Theory Experiment Said to Prove ‘Spooky’ Interactions
item.description: A study in the Netherlands backs up a long-held claim of quantum theory, one that Einstein refused to accept, that objects separated by great distance could affect each other’s behavior.
item.dc:creator: JOHN MARKOFF
item.media:description: A lab setup used in a test that supported the most fundamental claims of the theory of quantum mechanics at Delft University of Technology.

item.title: U.N. Envoy Says Libya Peace Process Will Continue
item.description: Despite rejections announced by hard-liners in both political factions recently, the envoy said he was hopeful that a vote would soon go before Parliament.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Unesco Resolution Criticizes Israel Over Handling of Holy Sites
item.description: The United Nations’ cultural heritage agency cited “illegal measures” to limit Muslims’ access to Al Aqsa Mosque compound in Jerusalem, but omitted a plan to classify the Western Wall as part of it.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The Western Wall in Jerusalem, shown in March, was added to the Unesco World Heritage List in 1981.

item.title: South African Students Clash With Police in Cape Town Over Tuition
item.description: Hundreds of students protesting a planned 6 percent tuition increase tried to force their way into the Parliament building during a speech by the finance minister.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: South African students tried to force their way through the gates of Parliament on Wednesday during clashes with the police in Cape Town.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Shopping Trip Turns Deadly for Mainland Tourist
item.description: Tensions between residents in Hong Kong and their compatriots in mainland China worsened, as resentment erupted over the death of a mainland tourist in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW and VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: An organized tour group of mainland Chinese assembling for jewelry shopping in the Hung Hom area of Hong Kong.

item.title: Iran Nuclear Deal Wins Tepid Endorsement From Ayatollah Ali Khamenei
item.description: The provisional backing by the supreme leader was accompanied by a warning that Tehran expected all sanctions to be lifted or it would walk away from the deal.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Office of the Iranian Supreme Leader, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, during a meeting in Tehran on Monday.

item.title: Assad Makes Unannounced Trip to Moscow to Discuss Syria With Putin
item.description: The leaders talked about their joint military campaign and a future political transition in Syria, a Kremlin spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: 2 Chinese Diplomats Shot to Death in Philippines
item.description: A Chinese citizen has been arrested in the shooting in the central city of Cebu, which also left the consul general, Song Ronghua, wounded, officials said.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.media:description: A Chinese interpreter, center, sat with the Chinese couple detained in the shooting in Cebu: Li Qinglong, right, and his wife, Gou Jing.

item.title: Marine Pilot Dies in Jet Crash in Britain
item.description: The crash happened shortly after takeoff from a Royal Air Force base in Lakenheath, England, about 80 miles northeast of London, the authorities said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: United States military personnel surveying the scene near the site of a plane crash in Cambridgeshire, England, on Wednesday.

item.title: Mariupol Journal: Sounds of War Recede to Background in an Eastern Ukraine City
item.description: Mariupol was on the front lines of separatist battles just months ago, but the conflict has been at a low simmer, creating an odd normalcy in the port city.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: First-year students at School 68 in Mariupol arrived for a welcoming assembly in September on the first day of the school year.

item.title: Arab Proposal to U.N. Over Western Wall Stirs New Concern
item.description: United Nations officials have objected to an Arab proposal to make Judaism’s holiest site part of the Al Aqsa Mosque compound in Jerusalem.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: An Israeli man prayed at the Western Wall, one of the holiest sites in Judaism.

item.title: Netanyahu Draws Broad Criticism After Saying a Palestinian Inspired Holocaust
item.description: Israeli historians and opposition politicians joined Palestinians in denouncing the Israeli prime minister for saying the grand mufti of Jerusalem gave Hitler the idea of annihilating Jews.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Adolf Hitler talking to Haj Amin al-Husseini, the grand mufti of Jerusalem. The mufti helped instigate Arab pogroms against Jews in the holy land in the 1920s and collaborated with the Nazis.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Next Refugee Crisis: Afghanistan
item.description: As Pakistan and Iran turn cold to them, desperate Afghans are swelling the flow to Europe.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL KUGELMAN

item.title: E.U. Orders 2 Nations to Recover Taxes From Starbucks and Fiat
item.description: The European Union said that the countries had given the companies unfair state aid by letting them shift profits and pay lower tax rates.
item.category: Fiat Finance and Trade Ltd SA
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Margrethe Vestager, the antitrust chief of the European Union, at a news conference in Brussels on Wednesday.

item.title: Singapore Megachurch Founder Is Convicted of Fraud
item.description: A judge found that the founder, Kong Hee, and five other church officials had misused millions in church funds to support the music career of Mr. Kong’s wife.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Ridicule Turns to Affection as Chinese Social Media Embraces Jiang Zemin
item.description: After years of mockery, Mr. Jiang has emerged as something of a cult figure, the idol at the center of a tongue-in-cheek subculture known as “toad worship culture.”
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
Chinese University of Hong Kong, The
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:description: A leader's conduct, which once provoked embarrassment, is recalled by many Chinese today as endearingly idiosyncratic. Jiang Zemin, then the Chinese president, touching up his hair as King Juan Carlos of Spain looked on at a reception in Madrid in June 1996.

item.title: China Turns to Online Courses, and Mao, for Soft-Power Mission
item.description: Offerings on a range of subjects could expose millions of overseas students to Chinese culture, if worries about academic freedom, quality and propaganda can be overcome.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.media:description: Guards changing shifts beneath the portrait of the former Chinese leader Mao Zedong at Tiananmen Gate in Beijing after a flag-raising ceremony this month.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Are We Losing Afghanistan Again?
item.description: As American troops are leaving, Al Qaeda is returning.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: THOMAS JOSCELYN and BILL ROGGIO
item.media:description: Taliban militants in eastern Afghanistan last week.
